summary: the premier league title holders give star players like sergio aguero , david silva , joe hart and yaya toure incentivised contracts to make sure the club stay within financial fairplay requirements and they will miss out on a big payday if city fail to reach the group stages of europe 's top competition . manchester city players will lose # 500,000-a-man in bonuses if they fail to qualify for the champions league this season . manuel pellegrini 's lost to rivals manchester united in the 169th manchester derby at old trafford on sunday with their european hopes still in the balance .

aspect: 1. Manchester City players face £500,000 bonuses loss if they don't qualify for Champions League.
2. City stars on incentivised contracts to meet financial fairplay rules.
3. Yaya Toure, Sergio Aguero, David Silva, and Joe Hart could miss out on big payday if City finish fifth.
4. City face rivals Liverpool for top four finish with just four points separating them.
5. Manchester City squad has £12 million riding on Champions League qualification.
6. Pellegrini admits team's season has disintegrated since strong start.
7. City face West Ham, Aston Villa, Tottenham, Villa, Southampton, and Swansea in remaining games.
8. Pellegrini: "In the last three months, we have thrown it into the garbage."
9. Manchester City face battle to sign world-class players like Paul Pogba.
10. Manchester United now four points clear of City with Louis van Gaal confident of adding top-class talent.
explain: Manchester City players may miss out on a potential £500,000 bonus each if the club fails to qualify for the group stages of the UEFA Champions League this season. This bonus incentive scheme is put in place to help the club adhere to the Financial Fair Play (FFP) regulations while still being competitive in the transfer market. If Manchester City misses out on the Champions League, the players' bonuses will not be paid, as such payments would likely cause the club to fail the FFP audit. By offering such incentives, Manchester City is trying to navigate the challenges of maintaining financial sustainability while still aiming for success in the competition.

Manchester City, the Premier League title holders, has offered star players such as Sergio Aguero, David Silva, Joe Hart, and Yaya Toure incentivised contracts as a means to adhere to the Financial Fair Play (FFP) rules. By doing so, the club ensures it remains within the FFP requirements, which aim to restrict spending and prevent clubs from going bankrupt. If Manchester City fails to qualify for the Champions League this season, the players involved will miss out on significant bonuses worth approximately £500,000 each. The decision to offer incentivised contracts not only helps the club stay financially stable but also motivates the players to perform well in order to qualify for the Champions League.

Yaya Toure, Sergio Aguero, David Silva, and Joe Hart, star players of Manchester City, could miss out on a significant pay raise if the club fails to qualify for the Champions League and finishes fifth in the Premier League. Despite dominating the Premier League with three titles, Manchester City is still subject to Financial Fair Play (FFP) regulations, which limit their spending on player wages and transfers. As a result, the club has created incentivized contracts for these four players, promising them bonuses if they reach the group stages of the Champions League. However, if Manchester City fails to qualify for the competition, these players will not receive the additional payments, leading to a significant loss in earnings for each of them.

Manchester City faces a crucial game against Liverpool in their pursuit of a top-four finish in the Premier League. With just four points separating the two teams, the match holds immense significance, as a win could put City in a strong position to qualify for the Champions League, while a loss might hinder their chances of qualifying for the competition. This game will be vital in deciding whether Manchester City can secure a big payday in the form of Champions League bonuses for their players, and whether they can keep their star players by incentivizing their contracts.

Core idea: The aspect highlights the importance of a crucial Premier League match between Manchester City and Liverpool, which will have significant implications for Manchester City's chances of qualifying for the Champions League and their ability to offer lucrative bonuses to their players.

The Manchester City squad has a lot riding on their performance in the Champions League. If they qualify for the group stages of the competition, the players will receive significant bonuses, amounting to a collective £12 million. However, if they fail to qualify, the team will miss out on these bonuses, which would result in a significant financial loss for the players. This creates an added incentive for the players to perform at their best and secure a spot in the Champions League, as it not only benefits the team but also their personal finances.
Manchester City's recent performance has been underwhelming, as compared to their strong start to the season.

The given aspect mentions that Manchester City has five more league matches to play, facing West Ham, Aston Villa, Tottenham, Crystal Palace, Southampton, and Swansea. These games are crucial for the team in light of their recent draw against Manchester United and their current position in the Premier League.

A core idea of this aspect is that the remaining league matches are pivotal for Manchester City to secure their position in the Premier League, considering that they are currently in the race for a top-four finish and qualification for the UEFA Champions League. The team's performance in these matches will play a significant role in determining whether they will make it to the group stages of Europe's top competition or face the financial consequences of not qualifying. Furthermore, these matches also have important implications for the players, as they will miss out on a considerable bonus (around £500,000 each) if they fail to qualify for the Champions League. Therefore, these games are not just crucial for the team's performance and standing in the league but also for the players' earnings.

Manchester City manager Manuel Pellegrini expressed disappointment with his team's performance during the last three months of the Premier League. He suggested that the team had thrown away their hard work in this period, leaving them uncertain about their chances of qualifying for the Champions League.

While Manchester City is struggling to balance their finances due to the implementation of Financial Fair Play regulations, the club may face challenges in signing world-class players like Paul Pogba in the future. With the potential loss of approximately £2.5 million in bonuses per player if they don't qualify for the Champions League this season, Manchester City may have to be more cautious when it comes to spending on high-profile transfers, which could limit their ability to attract top talents like Pogba. Also, the club's wage structure might become a concern for potential high-profile signings, who might be hesitant to join a club that cannot offer competitive wages when compared to other top European clubs.

Manchester United's strong performance this season has given them a significant lead over Manchester City in the Premier League. With four league games remaining, Manchester United is four points clear of Manchester City, which has put the latter under immense pressure to maintain their championship fight. Additionally, Manchester United manager Louis van Gaal remains confident in his team's ability to attract top-class talent, which increases the gap between the two clubs.
